solarSystemObjects.name: The Sun
solarSystemObjects.tagline: Our Solar System's Star and Source of Life
solarSystemObjects.description: The Sun is the star at the center of our Solar System. It is a nearly perfect sphere of hot plasma, heated to incandescence by nuclear fusion reactions in its core, radiating the energy mainly as light, ultraviolet, and infrared radiation. It is by far the most important source of energy for life on Earth.

articles.title: Inside the Sun: A Nuclear Furnace
articles.description: Explore the core of the Sun and the nuclear fusion processes that power it.

articles.title: Solar Weather: Flares, Storms, and Their Impact
articles.description: Learn about solar activity and how it affects Earth and the solar system.

solarSystemObjects.name: Mercury
solarSystemObjects.tagline: The Swiftest Planet, Closest to the Sun
solarSystemObjects.description: Mercury is the smallest planet in our Solar System and the closest to the Sun. Its orbit takes it around the Sun once every 88 Earth days. It has a very thin atmosphere (exosphere) and extreme temperature variations between its sunlit and shadowed sides.
solarSystemObjects.dayLength: 59 Earth days (solar day is 176 Earth days)
solarSystemObjects.atmosphere: Thin exosphere (Oxygen, Sodium, Hydrogen, Helium, Potassium)
notableFeatures: Possible water ice in polar craters

articles.title: Mercury's Scorched Surface
articles.description: A closer look at the extreme conditions and geological features of the innermost planet.

solarSystemObjects.name: Venus
solarSystemObjects.tagline: Earth's Twin, Shrouded in a Toxic Veil
solarSystemObjects.description: Venus is the second planet from the Sun and is similar in size and structure to Earth. It has a thick, toxic atmosphere composed primarily of carbon dioxide, creating an extreme greenhouse effect that makes it the hottest planet in our solar system.
solarSystemObjects.atmosphere: Carbon Dioxide (96.5%), Nitrogen (3.5%), Sulfuric acid clouds
notableFeatures: Volcanic plains and mountains (e.g., Maxwell Montes)

articles.title: Venus: The Runaway Greenhouse
articles.description: Understanding the extreme atmospheric conditions on Venus.

solarSystemObjects.name: Earth
solarSystemObjects.tagline: Our Pale Blue Dot, Teeming with Life
solarSystemObjects.description: Earth is the third planet from the Sun and the only astronomical object known to harbor life. About 29.2% of Earth's surface is land consisting of continents and islands. The remaining 70.8% is covered with water, mostly by oceans, seas, gulfs, and other salt-water bodies.

articles.title: Earth's Unique Atmosphere
articles.description: A deep dive into the layers and composition of our protective atmosphere.

articles.title: The Blue Marble: Oceans of Earth
articles.description: Exploring the vast oceans that cover our planet and their role in climate.

solarSystemObjects.name: The Moon
solarSystemObjects.tagline: Earth's Constant Companion and Celestial Neighbor
solarSystemObjects.description: The Moon is Earth's only natural satellite. It is the fifth largest moon in the Solar System and the largest relative to the size of its planet. It plays a crucial role in stabilizing Earth's wobble and moderating our climate. The Moon's surface is characterized by impact craters, maria (dark volcanic plains), and highlands.
solarSystemObjects.atmosphere: Very thin exosphere (Helium, Neon, Argon, Hydrogen)
notableFeatures: Water ice in permanently shadowed polar craters

articles.title: Missions to the Moon: A History of Lunar Exploration
articles.description: From Apollo landings to modern orbiters and rovers.

articles.title: The Lunar Surface: Craters, Maria, and Regolith
articles.description: Exploring the geology and features of our natural satellite.

solarSystemObjects.name: Mars
solarSystemObjects.tagline: The Red Planet, Our Neighbor with a Mysterious Past
solarSystemObjects.description: Mars is the fourth planet from the Sun and the second-smallest planet in our Solar System, being larger than only Mercury. It is often called the "Red Planet" due to the iron oxide prevalent on its surface, which gives it a reddish appearance. Mars has a thin atmosphere, polar ice caps, and diverse geological features, including the largest volcano and deepest canyon in the Solar System.
solarSystemObjects.atmosphere: Carbon Dioxide (95%), Nitrogen, Argon, trace Oxygen & Water Vapor
notableFeatures: Polar ice caps (water and CO2 ice)
Evidence of ancient rivers and lakes

articles.title: Searching for Life on Mars
articles.description: An overview of past, present, and future missions looking for signs of life.

articles.title: The Geology of Mars: Volcanoes, Canyons, and Dust Storms
articles.description: Exploring the diverse and extreme geological landscapes of the Red Planet.

solarSystemObjects.name: Asteroid Belt
solarSystemObjects.tagline: The Rocky Remnants Between Mars and Jupiter
solarSystemObjects.description: The asteroid belt is a torus-shaped region in the Solar System, located roughly between the orbits of the planets Jupiter and Mars. It contains a great many solid, irregularly shaped bodies, of many sizes but much smaller than planets, called asteroids or minor planets.
solarSystemObjects.estimatedObjects: Millions, with Ceres being the largest
solarSystemObjects.age: Remnants of early solar system formation
notableFeatures: Source of many meteorites that reach Earth
Dynamic region with collisions and gravitational influences

articles.title: Ceres: The Dwarf Planet in the Asteroid Belt
articles.description: Learn about the largest object in the asteroid belt and its unique features.

solarSystemObjects.name: Jupiter
solarSystemObjects.tagline: The King of Planets, A Gas Giant with a Great Red Spot
solarSystemObjects.description: Jupiter is the fifth planet from the Sun and the largest in the Solar System. It is a gas giant with a mass more than two and a half times that of all the other planets in the Solar System combined. Jupiter is known for its Great Red Spot, a giant storm raging for centuries, and its numerous moons.
solarSystemObjects.composition: Mostly Hydrogen and Helium, small rocky core

articles.title: Jupiter's Moons: Worlds of Wonder
articles.description: Explore the Galilean moons and other fascinating satellites orbiting the gas giant.

solarSystemObjects.name: Saturn
solarSystemObjects.tagline: The Jewel of the Solar System with Stunning Rings
solarSystemObjects.description: Saturn is the sixth planet from the Sun and the second-largest in the Solar System, after Jupiter. It is a gas giant with an average radius of about nine and a half times that of Earth. It is most famous for its spectacular system of rings, which are mostly made of ice particles with a smaller amount of rocky debris and dust.
solarSystemObjects.composition: Mostly Hydrogen and Helium, small rocky core
notableFeatures: Enceladus (moon with subsurface ocean and geysers)
Hexagonal storm at the north pole

articles.title: Saturn's Magnificent Rings
articles.description: A detailed look at the composition and dynamics of Saturn's iconic rings.

solarSystemObjects.name: Uranus
solarSystemObjects.tagline: The Ice Giant Tilted on Its Side
solarSystemObjects.description: Uranus is the seventh planet from the Sun. It has the third-largest planetary radius and fourth-largest planetary mass in the Solar System. Uranus is unique among planets because its axis of rotation is tilted sideways, nearly into the plane of its solar orbit. Hence, its north and south poles lie where most other planets have their equators.
solarSystemObjects.atmosphere: Hydrogen, Helium, Methane (gives its blue-green color)
solarSystemObjects.composition: Ices (water, methane, ammonia), rock, hydrogen, helium
notableFeatures: Extreme axial tilt (rotates on its side)

articles.title: Uranus: The Sideways Planet
articles.description: Exploring the unique axial tilt and atmosphere of this ice giant.

solarSystemObjects.name: Neptune
solarSystemObjects.tagline: The Windy Blue Giant at the Edge of the Known Planets
solarSystemObjects.description: Neptune is the eighth and farthest-known Solar planet from the Sun. In the Solar System, it is the fourth-largest planet by diameter, the third-most-massive planet, and the densest giant planet. Neptune is 17 times the mass of Earth, and slightly more massive than its near-twin Uranus. Neptune is known for its strong winds and dynamic atmosphere.
solarSystemObjects.atmosphere: Hydrogen, Helium, Methane (gives its deep blue color)
solarSystemObjects.composition: Ices (water, methane, ammonia), rock, hydrogen, helium
notableFeatures: Strongest winds in the Solar System

articles.title: Neptune's Turbulent Atmosphere and Great Dark Spots
articles.description: Investigating the dynamic weather patterns on the most distant planet.

solarSystemObjects.name: Pluto & Dwarf Planets
solarSystemObjects.tagline: Mysterious Worlds in the Outer Reaches
solarSystemObjects.description: Pluto, once considered the ninth planet, is now classified as a dwarf planet. It resides in the Kuiper Belt, a distant region of icy bodies. Other dwarf planets like Eris, Haumea, and Makemake also inhabit this cold, remote part of our solar system, offering clues about its early formation.
solarSystemObjects.age: Formed early in the Solar System's history

articles.title: The New Horizons Mission to Pluto
articles.description: Relive the historic flyby that unveiled the surprising complexity of Pluto.

articles.title: What Defines a Dwarf Planet?
articles.description: Understanding the criteria that reclassified Pluto and led to the recognition of other dwarf planets.

solarSystemObjects.name: Kuiper Belt
solarSystemObjects.description: The Kuiper Belt is a circumstellar disc in the outer Solar System, extending from the orbit of Neptune at approximately 30 astronomical units (AU) to approximately 50 AU from the Sun. It is similar to the asteroid belt but is far larger and composed mainly of icy bodies, including dwarf planets like Pluto.
solarSystemObjects.majorComponents: Ice bodies, Dwarf Planets (Pluto, Eris, Haumea, Makemake), Comets
solarSystemObjects.estimatedObjects: Hundreds of thousands of icy bodies larger than 100 km, and an estimated trillion or more comets
solarSystemObjects.age: Remnants from the Solar System's formation
notableFeatures: Remnants from the Solar System's formation

articles.title: Exploring the Kuiper Belt with New Horizons
articles.description: Discoveries from NASA's New Horizons mission beyond Pluto.

solarSystemObjects.name: Asteroids, Comets & Meteors
solarSystemObjects.tagline: The Solar System's Small Bodies and Cosmic Debris
solarSystemObjects.description: Asteroids are small, rocky objects that orbit the Sun, mostly found in the asteroid belt. Comets are icy bodies that release gas and dust as they approach the Sun, forming a visible coma and tail. Meteors (shooting stars) are streaks of light produced when meteoroids (small fragments of asteroids or comets) enter Earth's atmosphere and burn up. Meteorites are those fragments that survive to reach the ground.
solarSystemObjects.examples: Asteroids (Ceres, Vesta), Comets (Halley's, Hale-Bopp), Meteors (Perseids, Leonids)
notableFeatures: Asteroids: Rocky, metallic, can have moons.
Comets: Icy nucleus, develop coma and tails near Sun, highly elliptical orbits.
Meteors: Visible streaks of light from burning meteoroids.
Meteorites: Space rocks that land on Earth.

articles.title: The Difference Between Asteroids, Comets, and Meteors
articles.description: A clear explanation of these often-confused celestial objects.

articles.title: Protecting Earth: Asteroid Detection and Deflection
articles.description: Learn about efforts to find and mitigate the risk of asteroid impacts.
